posts.author: Chris Smith
posts.title: Apple mixed reality ambitions could result in... a revolutionary TV?
posts.text:
Home / News / TV News / Apple mixed reality ambitions could result in... a revolutionary TV? Apple mixed reality ambitions could result in... a revolutionary TV? 
  
Apple is working on a new television set that will incorporate ‘mixed reality technology’ according to noted tech evangelist Robert Scoble. 
Speaking at the Web Summit in Lisbon (via Wareable ), Scoble said the new TV set has been in the works since the time of Steve Jobs and will be revealed within a year. 
He said Apple has a whopping 600 engineers on the project, with the whole deal based around the tech from the PrimeSense start-up it bought way back in 2013. 
He said: “ Tim Cook and Steve Jobs, I believe, sat down and talked about the future of TV and in 11 months they are going to show you the future of TV – because they are building the PrimeSense sensor right into the television, into the iPad and into the iPhone… so you can do this kind of mixed reality. 
"Apple has 600 engineers working on it. There was a patent released this morning – they've been working on mixed reality, or augmented reality, for five years… minimum.” 
You may remember PrimeSense as the company that helped Microsoft create the criminally-undervalued Kinect Sensor. 
Scobel claimed whatever Apple unveils by October next year will “blow even his mind.” 
The patent he refers to involves an AR mapping system for iPhone, which will offer real time augmented views of a real-life environment. 
Where this would all tie in with a television set Apple is thought to have abandoned long ago remains to be seen. 
Does this all seem a little far-fetched to you too? Share your thoughts in the comments below.

thread.title: Apple Makes a Move to Get the Most out of Apple News App
thread.title_full: Apple Makes a Move to Get the Most out of Apple News App

posts.title: Apple Makes a Move to Get the Most out of Apple News App
posts.text:
Post 3Q16 Outlook for Mobile Device Stocks PART 3 OF 3 Apple Makes a Move to Get the Most out of Apple News App By Rachel Gunter | Nov 8, 2016 2:39 pm EST Shrinking iPhone sales probably won’t destroy Apple 
Does Apple ( AAPL ) have a life outside the iPhone? This question has become important in recent quarters as Apple struggles with shrinking iPhone sales amid stiff competition and market saturation. 
For the September quarter, or 4Q16, Apple reported a fall of 9.0% in revenue to $46.9 billion. The quarter was dragged down by weak iPhone sales. The company sold 2.5 million fewer units of the device compared to 4Q15. With iPhone sales accounting for more than 63.0% of Apple’s quarterly top line, pressure in the smartphone market worries Apple investors. 
But apparently, Apple hasn’t run out of options to grow its revenue and break its overreliance on iPhone sales. In a move that could give a footing to the company’s mobile news app (application), Apple recently inked a deal with Comcast’s ( CMCSA ) NBCUniversal to sell its ads on Apple News. Allowing experts to manage Apple News 
The graph above shows Apple’s quarterly revenue trend. Tapping NBCUniversal seems to indicate that Apple is handing over the business of selling ads on its news app to an expert. NBCUniversal’s network and expertise in selling ads could attract more advertisers to Apple News, thus generating more revenue for Apple. 
Ad publishers will keep 70.0% of the revenue generated from ads alongside their content on the mobile news app. Apple and NBCUniversal will split the remaining 30.0%. 
Although Apple News is still a small business, it seems to have a bright future. Apple launched its mobile news app in 2015, and so far, it has attracted more than 70 million monthly active users and more than 4,000 publishers. New competition 
In the mobile news business, Apple is competing for market share with Facebook ( FB ), Alphabet’s ( GOOGL ) Google, and traditional news organizations such as the New York Times ( NYT ). 
Other than Apple News, Apple’s other efforts to diversify revenue streams include Apple Watch and Apple Music . {"metrics":["Open"],"tickers":["AAPL","CMCSA","FB","GOOGL","NYT"],"ticker_names":["Apple Inc.","Comcast Corporation","Facebook Inc",null,"The New York Times Company"]} X

posts.author: Conor Allison
posts.title: Here's how you can get Apple's new MacBook Touch Bar on an old device
posts.text: Reaction to Apple's fresh MacBook line has been mixed. While the shiny new Touch Bar appears to be a welcome addition to a device due for a major revamp, it comes at a considerable price. Even the model without the dynamic bar won't come cheap, starting at £1,449. Don't worry yourself, though, because a pair of guardian angels/developers have figured out a way to bring you the Touch Bar without assaulting your bank account in the process. Okay, okay, so it's not the real deal, but a demo app is available on GitHub to provide you with free access to the tool. First spotted by 9to5Mac, the workaround can run on macOS via the Function key, or on an iPad through a USB connection. Related: MacBook Pro 2016 review: hands-on with Apple's latest high-end laptop If you're looking to run the cheat solely on your Mac, make sure you're fully up to date - that'll mean running macOS Sierra 10.12.1 build 16B2657 or above. Once you've downloaded the latest zip into your Applications tab and begun running the app, hitting the 'fn' key will bring you the warm glow of the Touch Bar. Except, y'know, you can't touch it. The iPad equivalent is a little more complex, as you'll need to load the app onto iOS and keep it plugged into your computer through a USB the entire time - no small feat considering the lack of ports available on Macs. You're not going to get the full experience with this, of course, but your wallet will definitely thank you. And if you somehow manage to win the lottery soon after implementing this shortcut, you can have the Touch Bar for reals. Want up-to-the-minute entertainment and tech news? Just hit 'Like' on our Digital Spy Facebook page and 'Follow' on our @digitalspy Twitter account and you're all set.

posts.author: wcax.com
posts.title: Now you don't have to buy a fancy new car just to get Android Au
posts.text:
By Kyle Wiggers
Provided by
Android Auto began as Google’s answer to Apple’s CarPlay : in-car entertainment software that would play nicely with your phone. It provided seamless access to car-optimized apps like Google Play Music, Maps, Pandora, and useful real-time information like traffic incidents and weather. Since Android Auto’s launch nearly a year ago, though, it has been relegated to expensive new cars. But all that changed when Google announced a major update for Android Auto, version 2.0, that enables the in-car entertainment system on supported Android devices and tablets.
It is a boon for folks with older rides. Previously, you could only get Android Auto in one of two expensive ways: buying a new car that had it built into the factory stereo, or buying and installing a pricey head unit yourself. “[We] know there are millions of older cars on the road that are not compatible with Android Auto, and many don’t have a screen at all,” Gerhard Schobbe, Android Auto’s project manager, wrote in a blog post . “We wanted to bring the same connected experience to these drivers too.”
Related: Android Auto review
The new Android Auto client, which supports phones running Android 5.0 or newer, provides access to much the same interface as the one on high-end head units. It is hardware agnostic, Google said, meaning it will work regardless of whether or not you have a certain car display or mount. It launches automatically when your phone is paired to your car via Bluetooth. It will include enhanced hands-free voice commands, which include improved accessing features in Google Maps, music, and messaging apps, that Google said will launch in the coming weeks.
For the uninitiated, the Android Auto experience centers around the home screen, which shows three cards containing the most relevant bits of information at any given moment. If you receive a phone call or text, you will see the content of the message. If there is a road closure ahead, you will see detour details. And if there is inclement weather projected for your trip, you will receive an alert.
Apps are the other half of Android Auto’s equation and the platform is practically overflowing with them. They are informally divided into categories. Navigation apps include Maps, which provides turn-by-turn directions with distances, ETA to destinations, voice prompts, and pop-up notifications about upcoming lane switches and turns. Among the music apps are Google Play Music, Spotify, iHeart Radio, TuneIn, Joyride, Stitcher, podcast player Pocket Casts, and NPR One, all of which show album artwork and playback controls. Communication apps comprise Android Auto’s built-in messaging client, which let you send texts and initiate calls with voice. Voice apps — principally Google’s autonomous assistant, Google Now — provide navigational assistance, allowing you to launch apps, begin music playlists, pull up directions, get the local temperature, and even learn about the elevation of nearby geographic features all by shouting commands.
Related: Kia offers Apple CarPlay and Android Auto for cars new and old
Android Auto on any old smartphone or tablet will not necessarily deliver the same experience as an integrated head unit. Hyundai, for instance, recently introduced MyHundai, an Android Auto app that provides access to Hyundai Roadside Assistance, monthly vehicle reports, maintenance alerts, and a Valet mode that notifies you if your car exits a pre-determined boundary. But it provides a pretty good approximation of the experience on head units and new cars. Considering it is free, perhaps that is good enough.
Google said more than 200 new car models from 50 brands now support Android Auto. The most recent to climb aboard include, Kia, which recently added Android Auto as a free software update on cars spanning model years 2014 through 2017, and Hyundai, which rolled out the platform as part of an update for certain models of the carmaker’s Genesis, Elantra GT and Tucson, and Santa Fe.
This article was originally posted on Digital Trends
Content provided by

Apple iMac 2017 Latest News & Updates: To Use Intel Kaby Lake Processor, Polaris 10 or Polaris 11 Chipset; VR-Ready PC? By Amy Westerly ,   02:00 pm Apple iMac fans have been waiting for an update to the iMac since a new MacBook Pro has been released. (Photo : DetroitBORG/YouTube) 
Cupertino-based tech giant Apple has been keeping mum about the new Apple iMac 2017. Rumors have been swirling that the upcoming Apple iMac will integrate the new Intel Kaby Lake Processor with a Polaris 10 or Polaris 11 Chipset, with an added bonus that it will a VR-Ready PC. Advertisement 
The Apple iMac users and technophiles were expecting the announcement alongside the release of the MacBook Pro 2016 last October. As of the moment, no description of any kind (specs, upgrades, etc.) have been released or announced regarding the much-anticipated replacement to the Apple's flagship computer. Speculations have it that insufficient supply of Intel's new Kaby Lake processor might be the culprit behind the delay of Apple iMac 2017. Since the MacBook Pro 2016 is already sporting Intel's latest Skylake CPU , it only makes sense for Apple to put a similarly new processor on their flagship model Apple iMac 2017. 
Plus, this could mean that the new Apple iMac 2017 might be sporting the new Touch Bar feature that debuted with the MacBook Pro. The Touch Bar feature is a touch-screen strip at the top of the keyboard that changes to display functions specific to the app being used. And if Apple eventually features the Touch Bar on the Apple iMac 2017 , there could be user mouse less or trackpad less menu-based tasks on the mix. This upgrade will be a good addition to the desktop user's productivity, though. 
The Apple iMac 2017 is also rumored to sport either a Polaris 10 or Polaris 11 chipset, which has led to speculations that the new Apple iMac 2017 might just be the new powerful VR-ready PC on the block. If this is true, then the new Apple iMac 2017 will possess powerful specs, powerful enough to become an ultimate gaming tool with its processor and chipset combo. 
However, bear in mind that all of these are pure speculations and none have been made official by Apple. But with the recent upgrades and features seen on the MacBook Pro, dreams can surely come true for us, especially with the new Apple iMac 2017. iMac 2016 Release Date, Specs: Apple Launch Event Today -> #AppleEvent

thread.section_title: Recent Questions - Information Security Stack Exchange
thread.title: How do I know if Google keyboard input is safe for use?
thread.title_full: How do I know if Google keyboard input is safe for use?

posts.author: Question Overflow
posts.title: How do I know if Google keyboard input is safe for use?
posts.text:
up vote 3 down vote accepted 
Valid concern for both Android and iOS now that Apple has enabled third-party keyboard options there. 
For Android, there are several security solutions with firewalls that enable you to cut off network access to particular applications, even if full network access is allowed in the permissions of those apps. Some require root access and I cannot personally attest to the efficacy of these applications, but several work with vanilla Android and are very well regarded. That said, "well regarded" doesn't mean secure—these apps pose the same threats as the ones you're trying to restrict. If it functions without root access, then—for reasons beyond my familiarity with the platform—they require full network access themselves. For apps that do require root access, they get root access which is even worse (and the act of rooting itself poses a significant security risk for that reason). I suppose it's a question of which entity you trust more: Google vs. a third-party developer. This can easily spiral into a debate over which entity would be most fearful of the law and bad press, but of course that is not sound as a sole consideration in the scope of information security; an attack prevented today is better than an attack today, justice served tomorrow. 
Not the easiest task to remove Google connectivity from your phone altogether, and the keyboard isn't going to be the bottleneck in a hypothetical breach on their part. Notwithstanding, there are keyboards that require neither root access nor any network access at all, although the user experience may prove dissatisfying/insufficient for your purposes. You can try Keymonk Keyboard which does not require any network access, but judging by the reviews it probably would not work that well for your purposes. One other option is to use something like LastPass or DashLane which I believe act as input methods like a keyboard does. Something brewing with 1Password that is worth looking into: they will fill in passwords without use of the clipboard (clipboard sniffing is another valid concern of this same nature, perhaps an even greater threat at the moment). All of those apps I listed could have their own ulterior motives. 
At the end of the day, trust is more or less a (sad) fact of comfortable smartphone use today, and it can be difficult to determine who deserves it/who will respect privacy/whose infringements are most benign.

thread.title: Nazem Kadri hit on Daniel Sedin a result of ‘just trying to go low’ | The Province
thread.title_full: Nazem Kadri hit on Daniel Sedin a result of ‘just trying to go low’ | The Province

posts.author: Rob Longleymore Rob Longley
posts.title: Nazem Kadri hit on Daniel Sedin a result of ‘just trying to go low’ | The Province
posts.text:
Ben Kuzma: Ex-Canuck Grabner grabs share of Big Apple spotlight with red-hot start 
Nazem Kadri sees Jannik Hansen coming for him after a blindside hit on Daniel Sedin Sunday in Toronto. Craig Robertson / Toronto Sun/Postmedia Network 
TORONTO — Nazem Kadri feels that when he’s at his best, he’s both giving and taking a hit and if that requires living on the edge, so be it. 
But the only worry the feisty Leafs centre had after clocking Vancouver’s Daniel Sedin with an open-ice hit on Saturday was that the Canucks star was all right. 
After avoiding suspension for the open-ice blow, which triggered a wild third period in the Leafs 6-3 win, Kadri defended the play. 
“For me, I thought I hit him in the body and that was the main point of contact,” Kadri said following the Leafs Monday practice, his first public comment on the incident. “I’m happy the league felt the same way. 
“I don’t know if there’s anything you can do differently. It happens pretty fast. It’s a very reacting type of play. I just tried to go low with it.” Nazem Kadri received a charging major for this hit on Daniel Sedin. #RGCL pic.twitter.com/FuUV6B5Ofa 
— Rogers NHL GCL (@RogersNHLGCL) November 6, 2016 
The Canucks felt differently, of course, as general manager Jim Benning relayed in a statement released on Sunday after the NHL’s department of player safety opted not to further punish Kadri. 
“I was on the phone all morning arguing our case,” Benning said. “We’re lucky because the way he fell, he could have been injured for a long time. 
“The ruling we got is that it wasn’t a late hit and from their (league’s) perspective, it wasn’t a hit to the head. But it was a player (Kadri) who could have held back for making that type of hit. We’ll have to live with it.” 
Sedin’s twin brother Henrik was even more outspoken after the game. 
“He has a history,” Henrik Sedin said of Kadri. “He plays over the edge. That’s when you have to pay. The league has to step up and show that’s not something we want to see.” 
But they won’t have to wait too long to avenge it. The fight-filled third period on Saturday will certainly build anticipation for a rematch between the two on Dec. 3 in Vancouver. 
But the Leafs seemed to relish the emotion associated with the win, the team’s third in a row. 
“That’s hockey, I’m sure we would have done the same thing,” Kadri said about the scraps that ensued. “That reaction was pretty standard for a team that was down in a hockey game and we hit one of their best players.” 
Kadri, who seems to have embraced the challenge of being a shut-down centre and the need to get under an opponent’s skin, defended his style of play. 
“Obviously, I want to play on the edge and I want to play gritty as well. All and all, I want to be hard to play against.” 
Meanwhile, the Leafs practised on Monday in preparation for a Tuesday home date against the Los Angeles Kings. With three victories in a row, the Leafs have the opportunity to extend a winning streak longer than all of last season. 
“It’s good for our group,” coach Mike Babcock said. “We’re 4-1 at home. We want to be real good at home. I thought our team played well last game and that we didn’t give up very much. And we were able to win a game without your goaltender being the first star, which is nice.” Jason Botchford joins John Matisz on Off The Post:

thread.title: Canucks Game Day: Gutsy Hansen to IR, Daniel dishes on hit, Chaput gets call, Isles lose Hamonic | The Province
thread.title_full: Canucks Game Day: Gutsy Hansen to IR, Daniel dishes on hit, Chaput gets call, Isles lose Hamonic | The Province

posts.author: Ben Kuzmamore Ben Kuzma
posts.title: Canucks Game Day: Gutsy Hansen to IR, Daniel dishes on hit, Chaput gets call, Isles lose Hamonic | The Province
posts.text:
Ben Kuzma: Ex-Canuck Grabner grabs share of Big Apple spotlight with red-hot start 
BROOKLYN, N.Y. — Points to ponder as the struggling Canucks (4-7-2) and Islanders (4-6-2) — two of six NHL clubs with 10 or fewer points — clash at the Barclays Center in the fourth of six stops on Vancouver’s Reality Tour. (4 p.m., Sportsnet Pacific, TSN 1040): Hansen to rescue, to injury reserve 
Jannik Hansen has a shoulder ailment and has been placed on injury reserve — unavailable for a minimum of seven days — and has returned to Vancouver for further evaluation. Chris Tanev (foot) has also left the road trip to be further examined. 
Neither is a good sign. Hansen has two goals and four assists, is a staple on the penalty kill and was playing on the first line. Tanev is a top-pairing defenceman whose name regularly surfaces with teams talking trade with the Canucks. 
The Canucks recalled centre Michael Chaput, 24, from the Utica Comets and he’ll play on the fourth line tonight, while the goal-less Loui Eriksson returns to the top line. 
Hansen’s exit comes after a stunning Saturday sequence. The winger suffered a shoulder injury on a hit from Toronto Maple Leafs defenceman Morgan Rielly and then fought Nazem Kadri, after the centre levelled Daniel Sedin with a predatory hit that did not result in a suspension. 
“He was fighting with a bad shoulder — and that says a lot,” said Canucks coach Willie Desjardins. “Towards the end of the fight he had to get out of there because he couldn’t go. For him to jump up and step in right away was good to see. The one thing you like out of that game was that we stuck together. You like that we cared. 
“If you don’t care, then you don’t have any emotion and you don’t battle.” Daniel dishes on the hit 
Daniel Sedin said the hit from Kadri was a blur. He had to be reminded that he actually scored off the 2-on-1 rush with Henrik Sedin before all hell broke loose and that the league doesn’t always see things the way he might. 
Kadri got a charging major but no hearing or supplemental discipline. 
“They made their decision and arguments and I really don’t have an opinion — I have to move on,” he said Monday following the game-day skate. “When you see the hit and after the game, I really didn’t know what to expect and obviously there was some confusion. 
“And everything happened so quickly. They have their rules to follow and try to do the best job they can. What I liked the most is the way we stood up for each other and you never want to see an injury (Hansen), but standing up for each other, I was proud of our guys and hopefully it’s a starting point.” 
Added Desjardins about the Kadri hit decision: “I was disappointed. It’s a coach’s job to take care of his players. We thought it was more toward the head area and that always gets you more worried. Our game is physical and there are always going to be calls teams disagree with.” 
Daniel Sedin will be happy to win 1-0 and 2-1 games. Daniel dishes on team skid 
As for the Canucks being on an eight-game losing streak and being beset by injury — Henrik Sedin suffered a shoulder injury here in Brooklyn last January — it’s all looking way too familiar. 
They beat the Islanders in a shootout and, two nights later, lost in overtime to the Rangers. They went 3-2-1 on a six-game road trip and scored 16 goals. They did surrender eye-popping shot totals of 40, 40, 48, 49, 30 and 30, but were at a respectable 20-18-11 and still talking playoffs. 
Now, all the talk is about being in close games despite being blanked in four of the last six and finding a way to win on this trip in which they’ve gone 0-3 and have scored just three times. 
“It’s tough with injuries and you’ve got to work through it,” said Daniel. “We believe we can score and we have those guys on this team. It’s a matter of putting that first one in and things will get easier. 
“And there’s a different feeling from last year. Our system didn’t really work, and we have to keep believing our system will work. We’ll take a 1-0 or 2-1 win.” Chaput gets another NHL shot 
The recalled Chaput has played 58 NHL games with the Columbus Blue Jackets and knows something about winning. 
He won a Calder Cup last spring with the Lake Erie Monsters, the AHL affiliate of the Blue Jackets. A restricted free agent, the Canucks signed the 6-foot-2, 204-pound Ile Bizard, Que., native on July 1, to a one-year, two-way contract that pays $600,000 US at the NHL level and $225,000 in the minors. There’s also a $350,000 guarantee in the AHL. 
Chaput has two goals and 11 assists in 10 AHL games this season and had eight points (2-6) in the 17-game run to the Calder Cup title. 
“It was amazing,” recalled Chaput. “You see what it takes to get through that long playoff run and it was a great experience that adds to the resume. It just helps along the way. I’m just going to bring my two-way game tonight, bring some offence because I’ve been with (Alex) Grenier and our power play has been working well in Utica.” Isles lose Hamonic to broken thumb 
As if the Islanders need more bad news. 
Travis Hamonic is expected to be sidelined four to six weeks with a suspected broken right thumb. He suffered the injury Saturday when blocking a shot in a 4-3 shootout loss to the Edmonton Oilers. 
Adam Pelech has been recalled, but the Islanders will suffer without one of their top blue liners, much like the Canucks minus the injured Tanev. 
“We’re going to have to make the best of it,” Islanders coach Jack Capuano told Newsday. “Travis was playing on the first power play, first-unit penalty kill, 21 minutes a night and alternate captain.” 
Pelech will play with Nick Leddy. 
The Islanders have failed to win five games where they’ve either held the lead or been tied late in the third period. They’ve also allowed nine power-play goals in the last six games. And the power play is only 4-for-35. 
OF NOTE — Alex Edler (shoulder) is expected to return tonight. … Ryan Miller and Jaroslav Halak get goaltending starts tonight. Miller went back-to-back here in January, making 47- and 46-save efforts respectively in a 2-1 shootout win over the Islanders and 3-2 overtime loss to the Rangers. … Coquitlam native Mathew Barzal, the 16th pick in the 2015 draft, has played but two games and the centre is scratched again tonight. Jason Botchford joins John Matisz on Off The Post:

thread.title: All eyes on possible 2017 NHL top draft pick Nolan Patrick | The Province
thread.title_full: All eyes on possible 2017 NHL top draft pick Nolan Patrick | The Province

posts.author: Steve Ewenmore Steve Ewen
posts.title: All eyes on possible 2017 NHL top draft pick Nolan Patrick | The Province
posts.text:
Ben Kuzma: Ex-Canuck Grabner grabs share of Big Apple spotlight with red-hot start 
Nolan Patrick, left, is a hot commodity. He also hasn't played in four weeks. Marissa Baecker / Getty Images Brandon Wheat Kings star has missed 11 games with upper-body injury and also pulled out of this week's Canada Russia Series games 
Vancouver Canucks fans wanting to track projected 2017 NHL No. 1 draft Nolan Patrick will have to continue to wait. 
Patrick, the 18-year-old Brandon Wheat Kings centre many are suggesting will be the first name called next June at the draft in Chicago, has missed the past 11 games with an upper-body injury and Brandon general manager Grant Armstrong said Monday morning: “We’re not certain when we’re going to see him back in the lineup. 
“We’re not ruling out anything at this point, but we also can’t rule anything in. We’re trying to make sure he’s 100-per-cent healthy.” 
Patrick, who is listed at 6-foot-3 and 198 pounds, has four goals and five assists in six games so far this season with the Wheat Kings. He had 41 goals and 61 assists in 72 regular-season games last year with Brandon, then supplied 13 goals and 17 assists in 21 playoff games for the WHL champions. 
It was announced last week that the son of former NHL winger Steve Patrick and nephew of ex-NHL defenceman James Patrick wouldn’t take part in the Canada Russia Series. The opening game was slated for Monday in Prince George. There’s another matchup Tuesday in Edmonton, before the set moves to the OHL and the QMJHL. 
Patrick had sports-hernia surgery in July, which caused the Winnipeg native to miss the Canadian World Junior team summer camp. Armstrong wouldn’t elaborate on whether that ailment is a factor in this situation. 
“I’m not saying anything about the injury, other than that it’s upper body, day-to-day,” explained Armstrong. 
Craig Button of TSN stated in a scouting report on Patrick in September that he had “all the capabilities to be the No. 1 centre teams can build around. Has an ease to his play, both physically and mentally, that he combines with excellent skill to impact the game in every situation.” 
Brandon starts their lone B.C. trip this season on Nov. 30 with a visit to Victoria. That’s followed by stops in Vancouver (Dec. 2), Kelowna (Dec. 3), Kamloops (Dec. 4) and Prince George (Dec. 7). 
Brandon finished the 2015-16 regular season at 48-18-4-2. They’re 7-7-3-0 so far this season. Along with the Patrick injury, they’ve seen defenceman Ivan Provorov stick with the Philadelphia Flyers as a 19-year-old. 
Armstrong was hired in August, taking over the GM role from Kelly McCrimmon, who moved into an assistant GM spot with the NHL’s Las Vegas expansion team. McCrimmon does remain owner of the Wheat Kings, though. 
Armstrong had been assistant GM for the Victoria Royals and was key in building that franchise. Before that, he had been head scout with the Portland Winterhawks.

thread.title: Canucks Replay: Islanders hand Vancouver their ninth straight loss | The Province
thread.title_full: Canucks Replay: Islanders hand Vancouver their ninth straight loss | The Province

posts.author: Harrison Mooneymore Harrison Mooney
posts.title: Canucks Replay: Islanders hand Vancouver their ninth straight loss | The Province
posts.text:
Ben Kuzma: Ex-Canuck Grabner grabs share of Big Apple spotlight with red-hot start 
Canucks vs Islanders. Bruce Bennett / Getty Images 
Things are looking up for the Vancouver Canucks as they get set to do battle with the New York Islanders. 
Granted, they lost their eighth in a row in Toronto on Saturday, but that night, they became a team . Before Saturday they were just a collection of dudes wearing the same sweater. Basically a Gap ad. No wonder they were so inoffensive. Now, though? Team. 
“It’s great to see us sticking together,” Daniel Sedin said when the smoke cleared. “The game got out of hand, but we stayed together.” 
You know who advocates sticking together? People that are stuck together. But I digress. Willie Desjardins echoed Daniel’s sentiment: “All you have is each other and I have no problems with our guys sticking up for one another.” 
It’s all very sweet. Forget the losing streak. The Canucks may not have won the game, or any games at all in two and a half excruciating weeks, but they were there for each other . It was less a Hockey Night in Canada telecast than an episode of Full House. And like Full House, it starred a set of twins, and there was lots of hugging. Old time hockey. pic.twitter.com/5mJM1U1uvy 
Plus white people everywhere you look . 
Sarcasm aside, it’s good that the Canucks have each other’s backs, especially since the league sure doesn’t . Considering all the troubles they’ve had, you’d hate to see this team start to unravel. (Admittedly, a team unravelling would look pretty much the same, but that’s not what it was, OK? This was a team coming together . Embrace the spin.) The Canucks lost as a team on Saturday night — as one — and that’s far better than losing as 19 individuals. It counts as 18 fewer losses that way. 
Speaking of 18 losses, if the Canucks want to avoid getting halfway to that number on their current slide, they can stop the streak at eight by winning as a team Monday night in Brooklyn. Maybe they will? 
They’ll have to do it without a crucial member: Jannik Hansen will miss the contest due to a shoulder injury sustained in Saturday night’s Miller-Boyett production . Here’s the lineup. Via @HockeyAbbs , Virtanen and Stecher out tonight (4:00 vs NYI, #TSN1040 ) pic.twitter.com/7KjEBD4GAh 
— TSN Radio Vancouver (@TSN1040) November 7, 2016 
Hansen’s a big loss. Of the nine Canucks who have scored a goal this season, he’s one of just five who’s done it more than once. Now might be a good time for Loui Eriksson to reassert himself as a first-line player. 
Meanwhile, Jake Virtanen is out with a bad case of your coach hates you . Jack Skille and AHL call-up Michael Chaput draw in on the fourth line. And on defence, Alex Edler returns, pushing Troy Stecher to the press box. He’ll skate with Philip Larsen on what has to be the worst first pairing since chianti and tuna salad. But no matter. This Canucks lineup isn’t about individuals. It’s about the team . 
Ryan Miller starts in goal. And Canucks Live starts now. Harrison Mooney November 7, 2016 3:39 pm 
If you’re wondering why Troy Stecher is scratched tonight, Grainne’s got the answer: the canucks scratched stecher because edler's back and nhl rules state that you can only have one marginally good dman dressed at a time

thread.title: Keyboard Kimura: Jedrzejczyk has potential to surpass Rousey’s accomplishments | The Province
thread.title_full: Keyboard Kimura: Jedrzejczyk has potential to surpass Rousey’s accomplishments | The Province

posts.author: E. Spencer Kytemore E. Spencer Kyte
posts.title: Keyboard Kimura: Jedrzejczyk has potential to surpass Rousey’s accomplishments | The Province
posts.text:
Ben Kuzma: Ex-Canuck Grabner grabs share of Big Apple spotlight with red-hot start 
Joanna Jedrzejczyk, left, fights Valerie Letourneau during their UFC 193 straw-weight title fight in Melbourne on Nov. 15, 2015. Andy Brownbill / AP 
Almost as soon as Ronda Rousey kicked down the door to the Octagon and ushered women into the UFC, the promotion has been on a search to find her successor — the next all-encompassing superstar to take over for the Olympic bronze medallist once she decides to end her career in the cage. 
Just as hockey had several “Next Gretzkys” who fell short and countless basketball players failed to shoulder the weight of being “the Next Michael Jordan,” the UFC rushed to brand a pair of competitors as potential heirs to Rousey’s throne, only to have them turned back before coming close to reaching those elite heights. 
What’s interesting about the company’s initial failure in cultivating a successor to the former bantamweight champion is that while Rose Namajunas and Paige VanZant were faltering under the weight of the increased scrutiny that comes with the unnecessary moniker, Joanna Jedrzejczyk is poised to inherit the torch from Rousey and potentially eclipse her accomplishments. 
In terms of performance, Jedrzejczyk is already running neck-and-neck with Rousey, who returns following her first professional loss and a one-year hiatus to challenge Amanda Nunes for the women’s bantamweight title at UFC 207 on Dec. 30. Both have six victories inside the Octagon. And while the Polish standout hasn’t dispatched her challengers as quickly as her American counterpart, Jedrzejczyk has been no less dominant, blowing out Carla Esparza, Jessica Penne and Valerie Letourneau in her first three championship assignments. 
Two things might allow her to surpass Rousey. 
The first is that Jedrzejczyk has already shown her championship resolve in the cage, rallying from being down two rounds against Claudia Gadelha in her most recent outing to defeat the No. 1 contender with style points when they clashed in July. Where Rousey looked like a deer in the headlights in her championship loss to Holly Holm last November at UFC 193, Jedrzejczyk never panicked in her rematch with Gadelha, eventually turning the tide and taking it to her rival over the final three rounds. 
Second, the undefeated 29-year-old has no plans to exit the Octagon for a career in Hollywood. She wants her stardom to come as a result of her exploits in the cage, and her talent and intangibles already have her well on the way to achieving legendary status in the sport. 
“I know that I’m not the prettiest one, I’m not having big boobies or I’m not American, but I want people to remember me as the best female fighter and the UFC champion of the world,” she said during last week’s UFC 205 conference call. 
The comment prompted welterweight champ Tyron Woodley to call Jedrzejczyk an “original gangster,” but it also encapsulates everything that makes her the true heir to Rousey’s throne. 
Jedrzejczyk managed to avoid the forced comparison with her bantamweight counterpart earlier in her career, quietly emerging as a potential superstar in the week leading up to her championship win at UFC 185 in Dallas, and they’re still not coming now. But if anyone has the potential to live up to, or potentially exceed, the level of success and stardom Rousey has achieved, it’s Jedrzejczyk. 
She’s already there in terms of performance, and her championship clash with fellow unbeaten Polish fighter Karolina Kowalkiewicz Saturday at UFC 205 in New York is another opportunity for the undefeated titleholder to prove her dominance in the cage. She’s also committed to widening her level of exposure and brand reach, moving to South Florida to train at American Top Team and making herself more readily available to the North American media, the value of which can’t be underestimated. 
“I want to build more and more my legacy and I think I’ve got more attention from U.S. media since I moved to Florida,” she said when we spoke Monday. “I know how important it is, not just for my career, but for the UFC, for MMA, so we need more and more MMA in mainstream media. I see that Ronda has done so much for this — Conor McGregor as well — and I’m happy to be part of it.” 
Just as positioning her alongside Rousey last year at UFC 193 was a savvy decision by the UFC, so too is including this bout with Kowalkiewicz in Saturday’s historic debut at Madison Square Garden. 
Jedrzejczyk is already a superstar within the MMA world and with the right opportunities, she too can cross over into the mainstream and become that “Next Ronda Rousey” the UFC has been searching for over the last couple of years. to report a typo. Is there more to this story? We’d like to hear from you about this or any other stories you think we should know about. Email .

thread.title: Canucks Post Game: More down-low woes, Desjardins looks down, Daniel cuts to chase, Miller miffed | The Province
thread.title_full: Canucks Post Game: More down-low woes, Desjardins looks down, Daniel cuts to chase, Miller miffed | The Province

posts.author: Ben Kuzmamore Ben Kuzma
posts.title: Canucks Post Game: More down-low woes, Desjardins looks down, Daniel cuts to chase, Miller miffed | The Province
posts.text:
Ben Kuzma: Ex-Canuck Grabner grabs share of Big Apple spotlight with red-hot start 
Cal Clutterbuck scores the game winner on Ryan Miller. Bruce Bennett / Getty Images 
BROOKLYN, N.Y — Points to ponder as the Canucks actually scored first Monday — only the second time in 13 games — but faded in the third period in a 4-2 loss to the Islanders to extend their losing streak to a sobering nine games: 
NO-GO ZONE BECOMES FREE-FLY ZONE 
Ryan Miller referenced all the bad bounces and rebounds landing on sticks or in the net. He referenced finding the collective resolve to turn this thing around. But what really has to happen is what isn’t happening down low. Did you notice? 
Did you notice the struggling Philip Larsen trying to get through the neutral zone like he was trying to tip-toe through land mines? Did you see how slow he was getting back on the Islanders’ first goal, a strange sequence where Anders Lee swatted a loose puck for an easy Jason Chimera goal because three defenders were watching, not engaging? 
Alex Edler noticed. 
Ryan Miller and Alex Edler. Bruce Bennett / Getty Images 
“I definitely think we can approve,” said the Canucks defenceman. “We have to be more aggressive down low. When they can control the puck and start cycling, that’s hard to defend for any team. We have to get in there quicker and react quicker and be more aggressive.” 
It’s almost as if the Canucks are trying to do too much. Erik Gudbranson slid early to stop a Thomas Hickey shot and he stepped around the defenceman and had ample time to shoot. The vacated space also allowed John Tavares to bat a loose puck to Nikolay Kulemin for the second goal. 
“There’s no doubt that everybody is giving everything and trying to get a win here — and maybe too much — but we’ve got to stay positive here,” added Edler. “We believe we have a good system and if we execute it, we will get wins.” 
DESJARDINS HAS THAT DEFEATED LOOK 
Willie Desjardins didn’t say much after the demoralizing loss. In a business where winning is everything, nine losses are weighing on him and a 10th on Tuesday against the Rangers would match a franchise record established in 1997. It cost Tom Renney his job. 
Keeping his club mentally focussed the rest of this winless trip is a challenge. 
“It’s tough,” he admitted. “You need some good results and it’s nice we got that first one (goal) tonight. We were there and we also got one on the power play, so some good things happened. 
“But in the third, we didn’t take it away like we needed to. We played our best hockey of the last five and to be successful, we have to play that way all the time. It seems we have to get behind before we get excited and really get going.” 
DANIEL CUTS TO THE CHASE 
Daniel Sedin opened scoring and said all the right things all day about how this system is good, how winning 1-0 and 2-1 games are the way it has to be because a better defensive structure will pull the club out of the muck. But when the wins aren’t there, then what? How do you sell this in the room? 
Anders Lee trips up Daniel Sedin. Bruce Bennett / Getty Images 
“We’re battling hard, but we’ve got to find a way to win a game,” he said. “It was nice to get the first goal because it’s tough to play from behind. You could tell when we got that first one that we felt a lot better about our game. 
“We have to go for that first goal. We can’t sit back because when they get the lead, we stop playing. But tonight we had a good start, but we need that every game. 
“When you have the lead, you can wait for their mistakes.” 
ARE THEY SLIP, SLIDING AWAY? 
Ryan Miller has the best seat in the house with what is and isn’t happening in front of him. On Monday, it was obvious. 
“On their second goal, we had two D-men sliding and that’s not really who we are,” said Miller. “You can’t fault guys for making the read and trying to be desperate. Even on the first goal, a nice block off the rush, a secondary block and they knock it out of the air and put it in the crease and score. 
“Even when things are going our way in tight games, we can’t afford to make mistakes.”

thread.title: Apple launches beta 2 of iOS 10.2, featuring new TV app and Music app UI tweaks
thread.title_full: Apple launches beta 2 of iOS 10.2, featuring new TV app and Music app UI tweaks

posts.author: Digital Trends
posts.title: Apple launches beta 2 of iOS 10.2, featuring new TV app and Music app UI tweaks
posts.text:
The second beta of iOS 10.2 has been pushed to developers, bringing a number of changes to the operating system, which will ultimately be pushed to consumers.
Perhaps the biggest change to iOS is the fact that it now has the TV app that was shown off during Apple’s October 27 event. The app allows users to view content from a range of other streaming accounts, although Netflix will not be among the list of providers at launch, according to reports from Recode .
More: Facebook gradually moving into TV advertising with Apple TV and Roku TV ads
Apart from the TV app, the new iOS 10.2 beta comes with a few design tweaks in Apple Music, and some new SOS features.
When it comes to the SOS features, users will now be able to press the power button five times to automatically dial an emergency number. The feature works in Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Canada, China, France, Hong Kong, India, Italy, Japan, Russia, Spain, the United Kingdom, and the United States. You can manage the settings for the new SOS feature by heading to the Settings app and scrolling to the General section.
The Music app has also gotten a few design tweaks to make using it a little easier. For example, the Shuffle and Repeat buttons have both been made a little more prominent, and you can simply swipe up to access those larger buttons.
Apart from the TV app and the new Music app, there are a few new emojis and a few redesigned emojis, as well as a new selection of wallpapers. You’ll also get the option to save the camera settings, plus support for a single sign-on, which lets users with a subscription to a cable service sign in only once to access multiple apps.

posts.text: share Apple is officially selling iPhones for the first time in its online store , as spotted by 9to5Mac . Prices are discounted by up to 15 percent off compared to new models. A listed refurbished rose gold 64GB iPhone 6S Plus is on sale for $589, for instance, and a silver 16GB iPhone 6S Plus is $529. Apple’s refurbished phones come with a one-year warranty — just like new iPhones — and include a new battery and outer shell. They’re also unlocked and don’t include a SIM card. Apple already sells refurbished Macs, iPads, MacBooks, and Mac accessories, among other products, but this is the first time the company’s putting its phones up for sale. The refurbished phones might be coming from Apple’s iPhone Upgrade Program. Now get out there and buy yourself a still-expensive iPhone.

thread.title: Ireland to formally submit appeal on Apple case this week
thread.title_full: Ireland to formally submit appeal on Apple case this week

posts.title: Ireland to formally submit appeal on Apple case this week
posts.text:
5:20pm GMT Ireland to formally submit appeal on Apple case this week A 3D printed Apple logo is seen in front of a displayed Irish flag in this illustration taken September 2, 2016. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo 
DUBLIN Ireland's government will this week formally submit its appeal against the European Commission's multi-billion-euro demand for back taxes from Apple ( AAPL.O ), Finance Minister Michael Noonan said on Tuesday. 
Ireland's cabinet agreed in September to join the iPhone maker in appealing the Commission's order that the U.S. tech giant pay up to 13 billion euros to Dublin after ruling the firm had received illegal state aid. 
Dublin is seeking to protect a tax regime that has attracted many multinational employers. The European Commission decision has also angered Washington, which accuses it of trying to grab tax revenue that should go to the United States. 
"The government fundamentally disagrees with the European Commission's analysis and the decision left no choice but to take an appeal to the European Courts and this will be submitted tomorrow," Noonan told a European Parliament committee in Brussels. 
(Reporting by Padraic Halpin; editing by Andrew Roche)

thread.title: iOS 10.2 public beta 2 with brand new ‘TV’ app has been released
thread.title_full: iOS 10.2 public beta 2 with brand new ‘TV’ app has been released

posts.author: BGR News
posts.title: iOS 10.2 public beta 2 with brand new ‘TV’ app has been released
posts.text:
Apple on Monday released iOS 10.2 beta 2, a freshened up version of its initial iOS 10.2 beta that had been released just one week earlier on Halloween day. The releases were a bit closer than usual, but Apple was apparently eager to get the new build into developers' hands. Why the rush? iOS 10.2 beta 2 is about much more than just bug fixes — it's the first version of Apple's iOS 10.2 software that includes the brand new "TV" app that Apple showed off on stage during its big MacBook Pro event in late October.
Now, following a successful rollout to developers on Monday, iOS 10.2 public beta 2 has been released, giving the public the opportunity to begin testing TV.
MUST READ: Hey Apple, why are you trolling us?
Apple's new TV app serves as a one-stop shop for online video. Well, almost — it doesn't support Netflix for reasons we explained late last month . But aside from Netflix, TV collects information about videos from all of the most popular services out there, such as HBO Go, Hulu, Showtime Anytime and much more. It allows you to browse and search videos, and it also makes recommendations based on your history. Then, when you find a movie or TV show you want to watch, tapping on it will switch to the appropriate app so you can begin streaming.
iOS 10.2 public beta 2 also includes a number of other features and refinements, including dozens of new emoji that arrive with Unicode 9.0 support. A face palm emoji, shrug emoji and a clown emoji are just a few of the additions you can look forward to.
Apple's new iOS 10.2 public beta 2 software is available to anyone registered with the public beta program as an over the air (OTA) download. To install it, simply go to Settings > General > Software Update and follow the on-screen instructions. This presumes you've already installed the public beta profile, which is available for download on Apple's public beta site.
If you're not already registered for Apple's public iOS beta program, you can register on Apple's website for free right here .
